text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- There was "appalling" information in the Bulgarian National Bank archives on how state funds have been siphoned abroad in the past several years, former interim Justice minister Haralambi Anchev said.
Anchev said between four and six billion dollars have been siphoned abroad shortly before the collapse of communism in November 1989 and after 1990.
-- Bulgaria's new Prime Minister Ivan Kostov said he expected central bank governor Lyubomir Filipov to resign.

-- Parliament tentatively decided to vote on June 27 to which anchor currency to peg the Bulgarian lev and at what exchange rate under an IMF-prescribed currency board system, to be introduced on July 1.
-- Bulgaria's new cabinet approved a proposal by the Privatisation Agency to sell up to 75 percent of the Kardzhali-based Olovno Zinkov Complex, a major lead/zink mining and smelter facility.
-- Greece's largest commercial National Bank of Greece opened a branch in Bulgaria to service increasing business links between the two neighbouring countries.
-- The central bank said it will cut its main interest rate to 43.08 percent annually from 51.48 percent, effective from Monday.
-- Industrial sales of Bulgaria's state and private sectors fell a real 17 percent in April year on year to 1,170 billion levs at current prices, the National Statistics Institute said.
